bill.constitutionalAuthorityStatementText: [Congressional Record Volume 169, Number 27 (Thursday, February 9, 2023)][House]From the Congressional Record Online through the Government Publishing Office [www.gpo.gov]By Ms. TENNEY:H.J. Res. 32.Congress has the power to enact this legislation pursuantto the following:Article V authorizes Congress, whenever two-thirds of bothhouses ``deem it necessary,'' to propose amendments to theConstitution.The single subject of this legislation is:Adding term limits to the Constitution[Page H829]

item.title: Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States to limit the number of consecutive terms that a Member of Congress may serve.

latestAction.text: Referred to the House Committee on the Judiciary.

item.title: Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States to limit the number of consecutive terms that a Member of Congress may serve.

latestAction.text: Referred to the House Committee on the Judiciary.

item.text: Referred to the House Committee on the Judiciary.

summary.text: This joint resolution proposes a constitutional amendment prohibiting a person from serving more than two consecutive terms as a Senator or six consecutive terms as a Representative. Terms beginning before the ratification of this amendment do not count towards consecutive term limits.

bill.title: Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States to limit the number of consecutive terms that a Member of Congress may serve.

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
